1.  <a href="/guides" class="decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100 no-underline hover:underline text-xs tracking-wide font-semibold uppercase flex items-center gap-1.5 contrast-more:underline contrast-more:decoration-current">Guides</a>

# Accessibility

</div>

<div class="grid [&>*+*]:mt-5 whitespace-pre-wrap">

## 

<div class="relative hash grid grid-area-1-1 h-[1em] border-0 opacity-0 group-hover/hash:opacity-[0] group-focus/hash:opacity-[0] md:group-hover/hash:opacity-[1] md:group-focus/hash:opacity-[1] -ml-6 pr-2">

<a href="#introduction" class="inline-flex h-full items-start leading-tight" aria-label="Direct link to heading"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon self-center transition-colors text-transparent group-hover/hash:text-tint-subtle contrast-more:group-hover/hash:text-tint-strong size-4" /></a>

</div>

<div class="flex-1 z-1 max-w-full break-words text-start justify-self-start leading-tight">

Introduction

</div>

If you're new to accessibility for the web, the *Web Almanac by HTTP Archive* has an excellent primer on the subject and the state of web accessibility that you should read before diving into this guide: <a href="https://almanac.httparchive.org/en/2021/accessibility" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">https://almanac.httparchive.org/en/2021/accessibility<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a>

> Web accessibility is about achieving feature and information parity and giving complete access to all aspects of an interface to disabled people.
>
> A digital product or website is simply not complete if it is not usable by everyone. If it excludes certain disabled populations, this is discrimination and potentially grounds for fines and/or lawsuits.
>
> – Source: <a href="https://almanac.httparchive.org/en/2020/accessibility#screen-reader-only-text" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">Web Almanac by HTTP Archive<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a>

People with varying disabilities use different assistive technologies to help them experience the web.

The <a href="https://www.w3.org/WAI/people-use-web/tools-techniques/" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">Tools and Techniques<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a> article from the Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) of the W3C covers how users can perceive, understand and interact with the web using different assistive technologies.

Some assistive technologies for the web include:

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  Screen readers

  </div>

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  Voice control

  </div>

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  Screen magnifiers

  </div>

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  Input devices (such as the keyboard, pointers and switch devices)

  </div>

When building accessible interfaces for the web, it's important to keep the three following questions in mind:

1.  <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

    <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'1.';--font-family:inherit;font-size:min(1em, 24px)">

    </div>

    </div>

    <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

    **Identity:** What element is the user interacting with?

    </div>

2.  <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

    <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'2.';--font-family:inherit;font-size:min(1em, 24px)">

    </div>

    </div>

    <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

    **Operation:** How can the user interact with the element?

    </div>

3.  <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

    <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'3.';--font-family:inherit;font-size:min(1em, 24px)">

    </div>

    </div>

    <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

    **State:** What is the current state of the element?

    </div>

In this guide, we'll focus on how to make drag and drop interfaces that are keyboard accessible and provide identity, operation instructions and live state updates for screen readers.

## 

<div class="relative hash grid grid-area-1-1 h-[1em] border-0 opacity-0 group-hover/hash:opacity-[0] group-focus/hash:opacity-[0] md:group-hover/hash:opacity-[1] md:group-focus/hash:opacity-[1] -ml-6 pr-2">

<a href="#building-accessible-drag-and-drop-interfaces" class="inline-flex h-full items-start leading-tight" aria-label="Direct link to heading"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon self-center transition-colors text-transparent group-hover/hash:text-tint-subtle contrast-more:group-hover/hash:text-tint-strong size-4" /></a>

</div>

<div class="flex-1 z-1 max-w-full break-words text-start justify-self-start leading-tight">

Building accessible drag and drop interfaces

</div>

Building drag and drop interfaces that are accessible to everyone isn't easy, and requires thoughtful consideration.

The `@dnd-kit/core` library provides a number of sensible defaults to help you make your drag and drop interfaces accessible.

These sensible defaults should be seen as *starting points* rather than something you can set and forget; there is no one-size-fits-all solution to web accessibility.

You know your application best, and while these sensible defaults will go a long way to help making your application more accessible, in most cases you'll want to customize these so that they are tailored to the context of your application.

The three main areas of focus for this guide to help you make your drag and drop interface more accessible are:

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  <a href="/guides/accessibility#keyboard-support" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">Keyboard support</a>

  </div>

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  <a href="/guides/accessibility#screen-reader-instructions" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">Screen reader instructions</a>

  </div>

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  <a href="/guides/accessibility#screen-reader-announcements-using-live-regions" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">Live regions to provide screen reader announcements</a>

  </div>

### 

<div class="relative hash grid grid-area-1-1 h-[1em] border-0 opacity-0 group-hover/hash:opacity-[0] group-focus/hash:opacity-[0] md:group-hover/hash:opacity-[1] md:group-focus/hash:opacity-[1] -ml-6 pr-2">

<a href="#keyboard-support" class="inline-flex h-full items-start leading-snug" aria-label="Direct link to heading"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon self-center transition-colors text-transparent group-hover/hash:text-tint-subtle contrast-more:group-hover/hash:text-tint-strong size-4" /></a>

</div>

<div class="flex-1 z-1 max-w-full break-words text-start justify-self-start leading-snug">

Keyboard support

</div>

One of the <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/using-aria/#rule3" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">five rules of ARIA<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a> is that all interactive ARIA controls must be usable with the keyboard.

When creating widgets that a user can click or tap, drag, and drop, a user must also be able to **navigate to the widget** and **perform an equivalent action using the keyboard**.

For drag and drop interfaces, this means that the activator element that initiates the drag action must:

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  Be able to receive focus

  </div>

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  A user must be able to activate the action associated with the element using **both** the `enter` (on Windows) or `return` (on macOS) and the `space` key.

  </div>

Both these guidelines should be respected to comply with the <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/using-aria/#3rdrule" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">third rule of ARIA<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a>.

The `@dnd-kit/core` library ships with a <a href="/api-documentation/sensors/keyboard" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">Keyboard sensor</a> that adheres to these guidelines. The keyboard sensor is one of the two sensors that are enabled by default on the <a href="/api-documentation/context-provider" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">&lt;DndContext&gt;</code></a> provider component.

#### 

<div class="relative hash grid grid-area-1-1 h-[1em] border-0 opacity-0 group-hover/hash:opacity-[0] group-focus/hash:opacity-[0] md:group-hover/hash:opacity-[1] md:group-focus/hash:opacity-[1] -ml-6 pr-2">

<a href="#focus" class="inline-flex h-full items-start leading-snug" aria-label="Direct link to heading"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon self-center transition-colors text-transparent group-hover/hash:text-tint-subtle contrast-more:group-hover/hash:text-tint-strong size-4" /></a>

</div>

<div class="flex-1 z-1 max-w-full break-words text-start justify-self-start leading-snug">

Focus

</div>

In order for the Keyboard sensor to function properly, the activator element that receives the `useDraggable` <a href="/api-documentation/draggable/usedraggable#listeners" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">listeners</a> **must** be able to receive focus.

The `tabindex` attribute dictates the order in which focus moves throughout the document.

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  Natively interactive elements such as <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/button" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">buttons<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a>, <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/a" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">anchor tags<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a> and <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLFormControlsCollection" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">form controls <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a>have a default `tabindex` value of `0`.

  </div>

- <div class="text-base leading-normal mr-1 flex min-h-lh min-w-6 items-center justify-center text-tint">

  <div class="before:font-var before:content-(--pseudoBefore--content)" style="--pseudoBefore--content:'•';--font-family:Arial;font-size:min(1.5em, 24px);line-height:1">

  </div>

  </div>

  <div class="flex min-w-0 flex-1 flex-col space-y-2">

  Custom elements that are intended to be interactive and receive keyboard focus need to have an explicitly assigned `tabindex="0"`(for example, `div` and `li` elements)

  </div>

In other words, in order for your draggable activator elements to be able to receive keyboard focus, they *need* to have the `tabindex` attribute set to `0` **if** they are not natively interactive elements (such as the HTML `button` element).

For this reason, the `useDraggable` hook sets the `tabindex="0"` attribute by default.

#### 

<div class="relative hash grid grid-area-1-1 h-[1em] border-0 opacity-0 group-hover/hash:opacity-[0] group-focus/hash:opacity-[0] md:group-hover/hash:opacity-[1] md:group-focus/hash:opacity-[1] -ml-6 pr-2">

<a href="#keyboard-shortcuts" class="inline-flex h-full items-start leading-snug" aria-label="Direct link to heading"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon self-center transition-colors text-transparent group-hover/hash:text-tint-subtle contrast-more:group-hover/hash:text-tint-strong size-4" /></a>

</div>

<div class="flex-1 z-1 max-w-full break-words text-start justify-self-start leading-snug">

Keyboard shortcuts

</div>

Once a draggable activator element receives focus, the `enter` (on Windows) or `return` (on macOS) and the `space` keys can be used to initiate a drag operation and pick up the draggable item.

The arrow keys are used to move the draggable item in any given direction.

After an item is picked up, it can be dropped using the `enter` (on Windows) or `return` (on macOS) and the `space` keys.

A drag operation can be cancelled using the `escape` key. It is recommended to allow users to cancel the drag operation using the `escape` key for all sensors, not just the Keyboard sensor.

The keyboard shortcuts of the Keyboard sensor can be <a href="/api-documentation/sensors/keyboard#keyboard-codes" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">customized</a>, but we discourage you to do so unless you maintain support for the `enter`, `return` and `space` keys to follow the guidelines set by the third rule of ARIA.

By default, the <a href="/api-documentation/sensors/keyboard" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">Keyboard sensor</a> moves in any given direction by `25` pixels when the arrow keys are pressed while dragging.

This is an arbitrary default that is likely not suited for all use-cases. We encourage you to customize this behaviour and tailor it to the context of your application using the <a href="/api-documentation/sensors/keyboard#coordinates-getter" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">getNextCoordinates</code> option</a> of the Keyboard sensor.

For example, the `useSortable` hook ships with an augmented version of the Keyboard sensor that uses the `getNextCoordinates` option behind the scenes to find the coordinates of the next sortable element in any given direction when an arrow key is pressed.

In order to let users learn how to interact with draggable elements using these keyboard shortcuts, it's important to provide screen reader instructions.

### 

<div class="relative hash grid grid-area-1-1 h-[1em] border-0 opacity-0 group-hover/hash:opacity-[0] group-focus/hash:opacity-[0] md:group-hover/hash:opacity-[1] md:group-focus/hash:opacity-[1] -ml-6 pr-2">

<a href="#screen-reader-instructions" class="inline-flex h-full items-start leading-snug" aria-label="Direct link to heading"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon self-center transition-colors text-transparent group-hover/hash:text-tint-subtle contrast-more:group-hover/hash:text-tint-strong size-4" /></a>

</div>

<div class="flex-1 z-1 max-w-full break-words text-start justify-self-start leading-snug">

Screen reader instructions

</div>

In order to users know how to interact with draggable items using only the keyboard, it's important to provide information to the user that their focus is currently on a draggable item, along with clear instruction on how to pick up a a draggable item, how to move it, how to drop it and how to cancel the operation.

#### 

<div class="relative hash grid grid-area-1-1 h-[1em] border-0 opacity-0 group-hover/hash:opacity-[0] group-focus/hash:opacity-[0] md:group-hover/hash:opacity-[1] md:group-focus/hash:opacity-[1] -ml-6 pr-2">

<a href="#role" class="inline-flex h-full items-start leading-snug" aria-label="Direct link to heading"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon self-center transition-colors text-transparent group-hover/hash:text-tint-subtle contrast-more:group-hover/hash:text-tint-strong size-4" /></a>

</div>

<div class="flex-1 z-1 max-w-full break-words text-start justify-self-start leading-snug">

Role

</div>

To let users know that their focus is currently on a draggable item, the <a href="/api-documentation/draggable/usedraggable" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">useDraggable</code></a> hook provides the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/Roles" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">role</code><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a> and <a href="https://www.digitala11y.com/aria-roledescriptionproperties/" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">aria-roledescription</code><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a>, and <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/ARIA_Techniques/Using_the_aria-describedby_attribute" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">aria-describedby</code><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a> attributes by default:

<div class="mx-auto page-width-wide:mx-0 w-full decoration-primary/6 print:break-inside-avoid max-w-3xl page-width-wide:max-w-full page-api-block:ml-0 table_tableWrapper__zr7LC">

<div class="flex flex-col" role="table">

<div class="flex flex-col w-full [&>*+*]:border-t" role="rowgroup">

<div class="table_row__LpfCG" role="row">

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

Attribute

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

Default value

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

Description

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_row__LpfCG" role="row">

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

`role`

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

`"button"`

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

The ARIA `"role"` attribute lets you explicitly define the role for an element, which communicates its purpose to assistive technologies.

If possible, we recommend you use a semantic `<button>` element for the DOM element you plan on attaching draggable listeners to. In case that's not possible, make sure you include the `role="button"`attribute, which is the default value.

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_row__LpfCG" role="row">

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

`aria-roledescription`

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

`"draggable"`

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

Defines a human-readable, localized description for the role of an element that is read by screen readers.

While `draggable` is a sensible default, we recommend you customize this value to something that is tailored to your use-case.

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_row__LpfCG" role="row">

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

`aria-describedby`

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

`"DndContext-[uniqueId]"`

</div>

</div>

<div class="table_cell__X_gFM" role="cell" style="width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%);min-width:clamp(100px, calc((100% - 0px) / 3), 100%)">

<div class="blocks w-full space-y-2 lg:space-y-3 leading-normal self-center **:text-left text-left">

Each draggable item is provided a unique `aria-describedby` ID that points to the voiceover instructions to be read out when a draggable item receives focus

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

The `role` and `aria-roledescription` attributes can be customized via the <a href="/api-documentation/draggable/usedraggable#arguments" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">options passed to the <code class="sourceCode mandoc">useDraggable</code> hook</a>.

To customize the `aria-describedby` instructions, refer to the section below.

#### 

<div class="relative hash grid grid-area-1-1 h-[1em] border-0 opacity-0 group-hover/hash:opacity-[0] group-focus/hash:opacity-[0] md:group-hover/hash:opacity-[1] md:group-focus/hash:opacity-[1] -ml-6 pr-2">

<a href="#instructions" class="inline-flex h-full items-start leading-snug" aria-label="Direct link to heading"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon self-center transition-colors text-transparent group-hover/hash:text-tint-subtle contrast-more:group-hover/hash:text-tint-strong size-4" /></a>

</div>

<div class="flex-1 z-1 max-w-full break-words text-start justify-self-start leading-snug">

Instructions

</div>

By default, each <a href="/api-documentation/context-provider" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">&lt;DndContext&gt;</code></a> component renders a unique HTML element that is rendered off-screen to be used to provide these instructions to screen readers.

The default instructions are:

> To pick up a draggable item, press space or enter. While dragging, use the arrow keys to move the item in any given direction. Press space or enter again to drop the item in its new position, or press escape to cancel.

We recommend you customize and localize these instructions to your application and use-case using the `screenReaderInstructions` prop of <a href="/api-documentation/context-provider" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">&lt;DndContext&gt;</code></a>.

For example, if you were building a sortable grocery shopping list, you may want to tailor the instructions like so:

> To pick up a grocery list item, press space or enter. Use the up and down arrow keys to update the position of the item in the grocery list. Press space or enter again to drop the item in its new position, or press escape to cancel.

If your application supports multiple languages, make sure you also translate these instructions. The `<DndContext>` component only ships with instructions in English due to bundle size concerns.

### 

<div class="relative hash grid grid-area-1-1 h-[1em] border-0 opacity-0 group-hover/hash:opacity-[0] group-focus/hash:opacity-[0] md:group-hover/hash:opacity-[1] md:group-focus/hash:opacity-[1] -ml-6 pr-2">

<a href="#screen-reader-announcements-using-live-regions" class="inline-flex h-full items-start leading-snug" aria-label="Direct link to heading"><img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon self-center transition-colors text-transparent group-hover/hash:text-tint-subtle contrast-more:group-hover/hash:text-tint-strong size-4" /></a>

</div>

<div class="flex-1 z-1 max-w-full break-words text-start justify-self-start leading-snug">

Screen reader announcements using live regions

</div>

<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/ARIA_Live_Regions" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100">Live regions<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon ml-0.5 inline size-3 links-accent:text-tint-subtle" /></a> are used to notify screen readers of content changes.

When building accessible drag and drop interfaces, live regions should be used to provide screen reader announcements in real-time of time-sensitive information of what is currently happening with draggable and droppable elements without having to move focus .

By default, each <a href="/api-documentation/context-provider" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">&lt;DndContext&gt;</code></a> component renders a unique HTML element that is rendered off-screen to be used for live screen-reader announcements of events like when a drag operation has started, when a draggable item has been dragged over a droppable container, when a drag operation has ended, and when a drag operation has been cancelled.

These instructions can be customized using the `announcements` prop of `DndContext`.

The default announcements are:

<div class="group/codeblock grid shrink grid-flow-col overflow-hidden mx-auto page-width-wide:mx-0 w-full decoration-primary/6 print:break-inside-avoid max-w-3xl page-width-wide:max-w-full page-api-block:ml-0" aria-busy="false">

<div class="flex items-center justify-start gap-2 text-sm [grid-area:1/1]">

</div>

<span class="button-content truncate">Copy</span>

``` relative
const defaultAnnouncements = {
  onDragStart({active}) {
    return `Picked up draggable item ${active.id}.`;
  },
  onDragOver({active, over}) {
    if (over) {
      return `Draggable item ${active.id} was moved over droppable area ${over.id}.`;
    }

    return `Draggable item ${active.id} is no longer over a droppable area.`;
  },
  onDragEnd({active, over}) {
    if (over) {
      return `Draggable item ${active.id} was dropped over droppable area ${over.id}`;
    }

    return `Draggable item ${active.id} was dropped.`;
  },
  onDragCancel({active}) {
    return `Dragging was cancelled. Draggable item ${active.id} was dropped.`;
  },
}
```

</div>

While these default announcements are sensible defaults that should cover most simple use cases, you know your application best, and we highly recommend that you customize these to provide a screen reader experience that is more tailored to the use case you are building.

<div class="hint transition-colors rounded-md straight-corners:rounded-none circular-corners:rounded-xl overflow-hidden bg-info border-info theme-muted-tint:bg-info-solid/2 [html.sidebar-filled.theme-bold.tint_&]:bg-info-solid/2 text-sm grid grid-cols-[auto_1fr] mx-auto page-width-wide:mx-0 w-full decoration-primary/6 print:break-inside-avoid max-w-3xl page-width-wide:max-w-full page-api-block:ml-0" aria-label="Information" role="note">

<div class="py-4 pl-4 text-info-subtle contrast-more:text-info">

<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="gb-icon size-[1.2em] mt-px leading-normal" />

</div>

<div class="p-4 pl-3 empty:p-0 -row-end-1 -col-end-1 space-y-3 [&_.hint]:border [&_pre]:border [&_pre]:border-neutral">

When authoring screen reader announcements that rely on an element's position (index) in a list, use positions rather than indices to describe the element's current position.

Here's an example of index based announcements and why you should avoid them:

> Item with index 0 was picked up. Item was moved to index 1 of 4.

Position based announcements are much more intuitive and natural:

> Item at position 1 was picked up. Item was moved to position 2 of 5.

</div>

</div>

For example, when building a sortable list, you could write custom announcements that are tailored to that use-case using position based announcements:

<div class="group/codeblock grid shrink grid-flow-col overflow-hidden mx-auto page-width-wide:mx-0 w-full decoration-primary/6 print:break-inside-avoid max-w-3xl page-width-wide:max-w-full page-api-block:ml-0" aria-busy="false">

<div class="flex items-center justify-start gap-2 text-sm [grid-area:1/1]">

</div>

<span class="button-content truncate">Copy</span>

``` relative
function App() {
  const items = useState(['Apple', 'Orange', 'Strawberries', 'Raspberries']);
  const getPosition = (id) => items.indexOf(id) + 1; // prefer position over index
  const itemCount = items.length;
  
  const announcements = {
    onDragStart({active}) {
      return `Picked up sortable item ${active.id}. Sortable item ${active.id} is in position ${getPosition(id)} of ${itemCount}`;
    },
    onDragOver({active, over}) {
      if (over) {
        return `Sortable item ${active.id} was moved into position ${getPosition(over.id)} of ${itemCount}`;
      }
    },
    onDragEnd({active, over}) {
      if (over) {
        return `Sortable item ${active.id} was dropped at position ${getPosition(over.id)} of ${itemCount}`;
      }
    },
    onDragCancel({active}) {
      return `Dragging was cancelled. Sortable item ${active.id} was dropped.`;
    },
  };
  
  return (
    <DndContext
      accessibility={
        announcements,
      }
    >
```

</div>

The example above assumes that the <a href="/api-documentation/context-provider/collision-detection-algorithms#closest-center" class="underline decoration-[max(0.07em,1px)] underline-offset-2 links-accent:underline-offset-4 links-default:decoration-primary/6 links-default:text-primary-subtle hover:links-default:text-primary-strong contrast-more:links-default:text-primary contrast-more:hover:links-default:text-primary-strong links-accent:decoration-primary-subtle hover:links-accent:decoration-[3px] hover:links-accent:[text-decoration-skip-ink:none] transition-all duration-100"><code class="sourceCode mandoc">closestCenter</code> collision detection strategy</a> is used, so the `over` property should always be defined.

If your application supports multiple languages, make sure you also translate these announcements. The `<DndContext>` component only ships with announcements in English due to bundle size concerns.

</div>

<div class="mx-auto mt-6 page-api-block:ml-0 flex max-w-3xl page-full-width:max-w-screen-2xl flex-row flex-wrap items-center gap-4 text-tint contrast-more:text-tint-strong">

Last updated 3 years ago

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>

</div>
